children.subject: There are seats reserved for L&S CS seniors.  The 8th reserve category says: " Seats Reserved for Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences/(Materials Science Engineering or Nuclear Engineering), or Computer Sciences: Senior Students or New Transfer Students"

Hm. It seems weird to write it differently for seniors than for juniors, e.g. it says "Seats Reserved for Computer Science Majors in the College of Letters & Science: Junior Students". 
The way this one is phrased makes it seems like it's referring to EECS/(Materials or Nuclear) (which are joint majors) OR EECS, not L&S CS, since it says "Computer Sciences" not "Computer Science".

But it's probably not a big deal anyway since 16B hasn't ever filled up completely before.

We do not write the descriptions of the categories. It's saying that seniors in those majors (EECS/MSE, EECS/NE, EECS, CS) have reserved seats.

EE16B is a required class for CS students who entered in Fall 2017 or later so if you're a CS senior next year, it's not specifically required for you.

Are there any seats in 16B reserved for L&S CS seniors? The 'Getting into EE classes' page says there should be a small number reserved for CS seniors, but I don't see that on the classes.berkeley.edu 'Reserved Seats' list.
186 does not have an instructor yet, so you can't enrol into it.
I am trying to add CS186 but it says "need instructors' consent". Does anyone know how I can add this class?
This is answered in the link Lydia included
Hello, are there any reserved seats for EECS sophomores (currently a freshman) for 16A? Really concerned about getting into the class. Thanks!

Classes seems to have a lot of typos for our enrollment priorities, unfortunately.

There are seats reserved for L&S undeclared and declared students at all levels in EE16A, except undeclared seniors, and undeclared juniors who are not transfers. The 70 seats for undeclared L&S sophomores are full.
Will this be expanded or do I have no hope of taking the class as an LS sophomore in wait-list position 200 next semester?

FYI, it seems like when you hover over the colorful bars on classes.berkeley.edu, the enrollment priority groups read correctly, but the titles to the left of the bars are not right.

Not sure yet. We're working on expanding the class, but will need to first prioritize seniors graduating.

If I understand this correctly, the reserved seats for 16A are:

  • EECS Freshman Students or New Transfer Students
  • New L&S Transfer Students
  • EECS Sophomore Students or New Transfer Students
  • Computer Science Majors in L&S Sophomore Students
  • EECS Junior Students
  • Students with Enrollment Permission

Did I misread the information, or are there really no reserved seats for L&S undeclared sophomores?

There appears to be space in several discussion sections, but I keep ending up on the waitlist regardless of which one I choose. I'm at position 219, and I don't want to fall any farther down the waitlist.
I believe that the system depends on "Terms in Attendance". So this would likely be the first one.
It is not based on units, it is based on terms in attendance. If you will be in your 7th or 8th term this fall, you would be a senior.

Is the definition of "senior" (with respect to EE16A enrollment priority) with respect to "Level" as seen on CalCentral (I believe this is based on units taken)?  Or is it based on "Expected Graduation Term"? (So to get enrollment priority, a senior would have to have an EGT of Fall 2018 or Spring 2019.)
Ugh. This is apparently a bug. I sent a helpticket earlier today. Hope that it's fixed soon.
This is now fixed.
If I'm not wrong the link still shows that the class is 954 students. When will the expansion and the new enrolment priorities be released on the website?

No plans to add dis sections; it would be a lab section that's added.

We have no possible way to accommodate every single student's preferred schedule.
regarding Update #4, if you're going to add a new discussion section to EE16A, my vote is to do it either at 11am or 12pm MW.  Too many labs and discussions for classes in the afternoons.
Some labs have open seats, but as of yesterday afternoon there were no available seats in the lecture.

Can you please tell me which labs are open? As I mentioned in my post, there is no way for me to check which labs are open because the schedule of the labs do not appear on the schedule planner and that other students(such as the student that posted after me) are unsure of the accuracy of classes.berkeley.edu ( I do not want to drop the entire class entirely in an attempt to join an open lab only to find out that classes.berkeley.edu was inaccurate and the lab I thought was open is actually full)

Are there any open spots for a lab still? I tried to check the schedule planner for other lab sections using all of the course status options, such as "open & full", but there are no available options. But on classes.berkeley.edu, it says that there is 1 seat open for a couple of labs. I am hesitant to trust classes.berkeley.edu and was hesitant even during the weeks before the semester started because the waitlist information would be incorrect. For example, I was number 72 on the waitlist for Lab 113 during the Summer, but it said that there were something like only 40 people in total on the waitlist for Lab 113. I did not drop the course to re-enroll because of the schedule planning issue.

also, on classes.berkeley.edu, it says nobody is on the waitlist for the lab im on the waitlist for (according to calcentral), and that it is fully enrolled. could it be that i am in fact fully enrolled in it?

If you are already enrolled, then "Options" would allow you to be put into the front of the waitlist for a full lab. Otherwise, no.

It's more likely that the course catalog hasn't updated yet.
Is there any way to swap into an open lab (according to calcentral), without dropping the course and getting put on the back of the waitlist?
Has anyone successfully enrolled in an EECS class that overlaps with a non-EECS class? Calcentral isn't letting me do so

history.content:
1. Enrollment Priorities for EE16A and EE16B can be found on classes.berkeley.edu. At this time, EE and EECS upper-division classes still do not have enrollment priorities.

     

    1. EE16A: We are in the process of expanding EE16A; I will update this post when I have more information about the total number of seats the class will be expanded to, as well as which categories of enrollment priorities will be increased. We recommend to all students who want to take EE16A to use Phase I.
      1. Fifth and final update, 8/17/18: Last expansion for EE16A! One more lab has been added, 121/121A. You can enroll in 121 or 121A, they are at the same time, same day, and same location. If you are waitlisted and want to switch labs, you must drop and re-add in order to choose a new lab. If you drop and re-add and are still waitlisted, see @7454 before sending an email.

      2. Update #4, 8/10/18: EE16A has expanded once again. See http://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2018-fall-eleng-16a-001-lec-001 for enrollment priorities and new lab sections. If there were more seats added to your category and your lab is full, you'll want to drop and re-add in order to choose a new lab. Otherwise, you'll remain on the WL. 119/119A and 120/120A occur at the same time, day, and location. They’re set up like this to enroll the most amount of students possible. It doesn’t matter if you enroll in the “non-A” or “A” section.

        Starting Monday with the Adjustment Period, there will be no more enrollment priorities and the waitlist will process in order. If your lab fills while you’re waitlisted, the only way to switch it is to drop and re-add the class. This will put you at the bottom of the WL, but you cannot be enrolled into a full section. WL’d students with full labs will be skipped over when the WL processes automatically. Check classes.berkeley.edu for open labs before dropping and re-adding. There’s a small chance that one final section will be added next week.

      3. Update #3, 8/3/18: Due to budgetary constraints, the faculty need to cap the lab sections with "A" suffixes. Will update yet again once I know more. Part II of update (8/8): All "A" lab sections are being consolidated into 1 lab. These labs have been closed and hidden from the schedule. The new lab should be on classes.berkeley.edu on Thurs afternoon. No other existing lab sections will be affected.
      4. Update #2, 7/23/18: EE16A has been expanded to 954 total seats. At this time, the extra seats are all being added to the EECS and LSCS senior category. Small new lab sections were created. Waitlisted students whose categories of seats are full may want to increase their chances by dropping themselves from the class in order to add one of the new lab sections; you are not able to switch secondary sections while waitlisted. We may be able to add up to 100 additional seats, but need to wait until the end of Phase II to see how many more seats we are able to add and which categories of students the seats will go to. I'll update again when I have more information.
      5. Update, 5/9/18: If you will be an EECS or LSCS senior as of Fall 2018 (including undeclared transfers who are submitting applications now and will be in their 2nd year), you must add yourself to the EE16A waitlist so that we know how many of you there are. We will first expand to allow more seniors to enroll; there will be no priority if you are graduating in the fall over the spring; it will go by waitlist order of seniors. We will add more seats to the EECS & LSCS senior category on July 23. If you wait to add yourself until Phase II or after July 23, we may not know that you need the class and cannot prioritize you later so we recommend waitlisting now. After expanding for seniors, we will see how many seats we have for other categories of EECS and L&S undeclared and declared students on the waitlist.

     

    1. 999 DIS Sections: Similarly to the CS side, EE16A and EE16B will have 999 discussion sections to facilitate enrollment. For EE16A and EE16B, you may be enrolled in one discussion section, but attend a different one. When adding this class you should choose the lecture, a lab section, and DIS 999. The schedules of DIS sections are visible on classes.berkeley.edu. You may attend any DIS section as long as there is a seat in the classroom. If the class is full, you will need to attend a different section. You must attend the lab section in which you are enrolled.

     

    1. Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted: Dissimilar to the CS side, if you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

     

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections.

     

    1. Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes. It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates.

     

    1. Enrollment Tips:

     

    • There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.
    • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20. These include waitlisted classes.
    • Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen? A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

Non-EE16AB Fall Updates:

  • EE 84-002 is canceled.
  • EE 130/230A will be taught by visiting scholar, Prof. Jaeseok Jeon.
  • EE 147/247A will be offered in Fall' 18. Taught by Joseph Greenspun who is Kris Pister's PhD student. The class is now open.
  • EE 221A will be taught by Prof. Yi Ma.

1. Enrollment Priorities for EE16A and EE16B can be found on classes.berkeley.edu. At this time, EE and EECS upper-division classes still do not have enrollment priorities.

      1. Update #4, 8/10/18: EE16A has expanded once again. See http://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2018-fall-eleng-16a-001-lec-001 for enrollment priorities and new lab sections. Otherwise, you'll remain on the WL. 119/119A and 120/120A occur at the same time, day, and location. They’re set up like this to enroll the most amount of students possible. It doesn’t matter if you enroll in the “non-A” or “A” section.

WL’d students with full labs will be skipped over when the WL processes automatically. Check classes.berkeley.edu for open labs before dropping and re-adding. There’s a small chance that one final section will be added next week.

      2. Update #3, 8/3/18: Due to budgetary constraints, the faculty need to cap the lab sections with "A" suffixes. Will update yet again once I know more. Part II of update (8/8): All "A" lab sections are being consolidated into 1 lab. These labs have been closed and hidden from the schedule. The new lab should be on classes.berkeley.edu on Thurs afternoon. No other existing lab sections will be affected.
      3. Update #2, 7/23/18: EE16A has been expanded to 954 total seats. At this time, the extra seats are all being added to the EECS and LSCS senior category. Small new lab sections were created. Waitlisted students whose categories of seats are full may want to increase their chances by dropping themselves from the class in order to add one of the new lab sections; you are not able to switch secondary sections while waitlisted. We may be able to add up to 100 additional seats, but need to wait until the end of Phase II to see how many more seats we are able to add and which categories of students the seats will go to. I'll update again when I have more information.
      4. Update, 5/9/18: If you will be an EECS or LSCS senior as of Fall 2018 (including undeclared transfers who are submitting applications now and will be in their 2nd year), you must add yourself to the EE16A waitlist so that we know how many of you there are. We will first expand to allow more seniors to enroll; there will be no priority if you are graduating in the fall over the spring; it will go by waitlist order of seniors. We will add more seats to the EECS & LSCS senior category on July 23. If you wait to add yourself until Phase II or after July 23, we may not know that you need the class and cannot prioritize you later so we recommend waitlisting now. After expanding for seniors, we will see how many seats we have for other categories of EECS and L&S undeclared and declared students on the waitlist.

     

    1. 999 DIS Sections: Similarly to the CS side, EE16A and EE16B will have 999 discussion sections to facilitate enrollment. For EE16A and EE16B, you may be enrolled in one discussion section, but attend a different one. When adding this class you should choose the lecture, a lab section, and DIS 999. The schedules of DIS sections are visible on classes.berkeley.edu. You may attend any DIS section as long as there is a seat in the classroom. If the class is full, you will need to attend a different section. You must attend the lab section in which you are enrolled.

     

    1. Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted: Dissimilar to the CS side, if you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

     

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections.

     

    1. Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes. It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates.

     

    1. Enrollment Tips:

     

    • There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.
    • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20. These include waitlisted classes.
    • Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen? A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

Non-EE16AB Fall Updates:

  • EE 84-002 is canceled.
  • EE 130/230A will be taught by visiting scholar, Prof. Jaeseok Jeon.
  • EE 147/247A will be offered in Fall' 18. Taught by Joseph Greenspun who is Kris Pister's PhD student. The class is now open.
  • EE 221A will be taught by Prof. Yi Ma.

Part II of update (8/8): All "A" lab sections are being consolidated into 1 lab. These labs have been closed and hidden from the schedule. The new lab should be on classes.berkeley.edu on Thurs afternoon. No other existing lab sections will be affected.
      2. Update #2, 7/23/18: EE16A has been expanded to 954 total seats. At this time, the extra seats are all being added to the EECS and LSCS senior category. Small new lab sections were created. Waitlisted students whose categories of seats are full may want to increase their chances by dropping themselves from the class in order to add one of the new lab sections; you are not able to switch secondary sections while waitlisted. We may be able to add up to 100 additional seats, but need to wait until the end of Phase II to see how many more seats we are able to add and which categories of students the seats will go to. I'll update again when I have more information.
      3. Update, 5/9/18: If you will be an EECS or LSCS senior as of Fall 2018 (including undeclared transfers who are submitting applications now and will be in their 2nd year), you must add yourself to the EE16A waitlist so that we know how many of you there are. We will first expand to allow more seniors to enroll; there will be no priority if you are graduating in the fall over the spring; it will go by waitlist order of seniors. We will add more seats to the EECS & LSCS senior category on July 23. If you wait to add yourself until Phase II or after July 23, we may not know that you need the class and cannot prioritize you later so we recommend waitlisting now. After expanding for seniors, we will see how many seats we have for other categories of EECS and L&S undeclared and declared students on the waitlist.

     

    1. 999 DIS Sections: Similarly to the CS side, EE16A and EE16B will have 999 discussion sections to facilitate enrollment. For EE16A and EE16B, you may be enrolled in one discussion section, but attend a different one. When adding this class you should choose the lecture, a lab section, and DIS 999. The schedules of DIS sections are visible on classes.berkeley.edu. You may attend any DIS section as long as there is a seat in the classroom. If the class is full, you will need to attend a different section. You must attend the lab section in which you are enrolled.

     

    1. Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted: Dissimilar to the CS side, if you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

     

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections.

     

    1. Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes. It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates.

     

    1. Enrollment Tips:

     

    • There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.
    • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20. These include waitlisted classes.
    • Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen? A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

Non-EE16AB Fall Updates:

  • EE 130/230A will be taught by visiting scholar, Prof. Jaeseok Jeon.
  • EE 147/247A will be offered in Fall' 18. Taught by Joseph Greenspun who is Kris Pister's PhD student. The class is now open.
  • EE 221A will be taught by Prof. Yi Ma.

#pin

history.content:
1. Enrollment Priorities for EE16A and EE16B can be found on classes.berkeley.edu. At this time, EE and EECS upper-division classes still do not have enrollment priorities.

     

    1. We recommend to all students who want to take EE16A to use Phase I.
